I oppose building a wall for many reasons, but I think the argument 
presented here is not very useful. Yes, higher travel costs leads to longer 
average time spent for those who go anyway, it's the same mechanism as with 
other travels: You don't fly to Asia for a 2 day visit and then go back 
again, because the travel time and cost makes it an inefficient use of your 
time and money. If you could go to Osaka in 5 minutes for a 2$ ticket, 
people would go there all the time. If Venezuelans could go to Boston in an 
hour for 50$, they would go there a lot more often than they are.
The primary result of increasing travel costs is to cut away the travels 
that are not critical enough or last long enough for it to be worth the 
costs in time and money. As a result, the average staying time increases 
because all those short stays are removed. A SECONDARY effect is the one 
you talked about: that many of those who go will then choose to stay longer 
while they are already there. That secondary effect is sizeable and 
relevant, but it is far, far smaller than the primary result.

I don't support a wall, that's why I want others who agree with me on that 
to not misuse statistics and economic theory like this. Using false 
arguments will only backfire in the long run.﻿
